GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: I definitely should go. I practically know that place inside out. You know, I was the original Bobby -- you guys don't know that. Yes.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: What happened?

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: It's because you look like Greg Brady, is that what it is?

GUTFELD: No, no.

(CROSSTALKING)

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: They're going to have to tell me later --

GUTFELD: All right. I was just trying to trick Emily.

Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

"SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hello -- Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Thanks, Bobby Brady -- or Greg, I mean.

Pageantry and politics -- President Trump visits Great Britain where he rubs elbows with the Royals and rubs London's mayor the wrong way.

Congress is back and promising more talk about impeachment.

And the deadliest weekend of the year in Chicago -- what's being done about it in the Windy City.

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening. Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier.

Love him or hate him, you have to admit President Trump makes an impression wherever he goes. The President is right now wrapping up a busy first day in London after a Monday filled with ceremony and celebration. He has been exchanging pleasantries with some of England's elite and counterpunching with others.

We start off tonight with chief White House Correspondent, John Roberts, who's traveling with the President. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret -- good evening to you.

And the President did just wrap up his day as the motorcade left Buckingham Palace just a short time ago. President Trump is a controversial figure in the U.K. to be sure. But while politicians here squabbled over whether this state visit should have happened at all, Elizabeth proved once again it's good to be Queen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

QUEEN ELIZABETH II, UNITED KINGDOM: As we look to the future, I'm confident that our common values and shared interests will continue to unite us.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: On behalf of all Americans, I offer a toast to the eternal friendship of our people.

ROBERTS: A lavish state capping off a day of pomp, ceremony, and controversy as Queen Elizabeth welcomed President Trump and the First Lady to the U.K. for what is just her third state visit of an American president.

At Buckingham Palace, the President reviewed the honor guard as they played American military songs. Then lunched with the Queen and other members of the royal family. Also present was Prince Harry, whose bride, American actress Meghan Markle, has been highly critical of the President.

In an interview with "The Sun" newspaper, President Trump said "I didn't know that, what can I say, I didn't know she was nasty." As that quote raced around the world, President Trump took to Twitter to insist "I never called Meghan Markle nasty." An audio recording shows he did say it but the President goes on to say I'm sure she will do excellently. Markle did not attend today's ceremonies, citing maternity leave.

President Trump did have some choice words for London Mayor Sadiq Khan after Khan wrote an op-ed criticizing President Trump as a figure head for a growing ultra-right movement. Khan wrote, "In years to come, I suspect this state visit will be one we look back on with profound regret and acknowledge that we were on the wrong side of history."

MAYOR SADIQ KHAN, LONDON, ENGLAND: Some of the things Donald Trump has done over the last two, three years -- Londoners find it abhorrent and offensive.

ROBERTS: President Trump took a blow torch to Khan, tweeting "He is a stone cold loser who should focus on crime in London, not me."

The President also got into a spat with Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn who boycotted tonight's state dinner. U.K. foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt said Corbyn's actions were out-of-bounds.

JEREMY HUNT, BRITISH FOREIGN SECRETARY: What is really inappropriate is for anyone to boycott a visit by the President of the United States. He's being hosted by Her Majesty, the Queen to mark the great friendship between our two countries.

ROBERTS: With the royal ceremonies wrapped up, President Trump will tomorrow meet for the last time with outgoing Prime Minister Theresa May. In an interview with the Sunday times, the President urged whoever takes over to do a no-deal Brexit by the end of October and sign a free trade agreement with the United States.

TRUMP: If they want to do trade with the United States. And I think there's an opportunity for a very big trade deal at some point in the near future.

ROBERTS: But President Trump raised some eyebrows here, saying he would like former foreign secretary Boris Johnson to be that prime minister.

TRUMP: He has been a friend of mine. He's been very nice. I have a very good relationship with him.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: In testing the ties that bind together the United States and the U.K., both the Queen and the President leaned heavily on the shared commitment and sacrifice that the allied countries showed on D-Day 75 years ago Thursday.

In ceremonies on Wednesday and Thursday, the President will commemorate that anniversary first here in England in the point at which the troops disembarked and then on Thursday on the shores of Normandy, where they landed -- Bret.

BAIER: John Roberts -- just after 11:00 p.m. London time. John -- thanks.

Let's talk about the President's trip and what's happening here in Washington. Senior political analyst Brit Hume joins us tonight.

Good evening -- Brit.

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: Hi -- Bret.

BAIER: You know, your thoughts about this. All this uproar, and obviously the pomp and circumstance of the moment.

HUME: Well, you know, these state visits involving these two countries really aren't about the personalities presiding at time. They really are about this relationship with this country that has been so close to us for so long, really since the American Revolution.

And we have stood together through thick and thin, and triumphantly through the dark days and then the victory in World War II and that's part of what's going to be commemorative this week, as it should be. And that's what the ceremony really is about.

Donald Trump may not be -- I doubt very seriously if Donald Trump is the favorite of the Queen but she spoke as she did about him and welcomed him for the same reason that he spoke about her in the way he did.

The relationship is bigger than any of this stuff between the politicians and you can see in the actions of the mayor of London whose popularity is down in a city which isn't particularly fond of Trump. So he takes Trump on and of course, Trump bites and bites back. Similarly with Jeremy Corbyn. So, you know, politicians do what politicians do but this relationship goes on.

BAIER: Yes. And the President is a counterpuncher, as we have said.

(CROSSTALKING)

BAIER: But you know, that The Brexit vote that was a preamble almost to the Donald Trump vote --

HUME: Right.

BAIER: -- would that spoke to something else was happening, this populism.

HUME: Right. Yes. There is an uprising that transcends, you know, our country and theirs. It's happening in a lot of places. And Donald Trump is certainly a result of that. And to some extent, perhaps the cause but more of a result. And so you see the strain that that cause as reflected but I think strikingly -- set aside by the people that mattered for the purposes of this visit, and that's a good thing.

BAIER: They are talking about trade and the possibility of direct trade between the U.S. and the U.K. Meantime, we have this Mexico situation and the possibility of tariffs if Mexico according to the President doesn't deal with the illegal immigration situation.

Here is outgoing Kevin Hassett as the White House talking about that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN HASSETT, WHITE HOUSE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS: The President is you know, very good at getting people to the table and getting, you know, concessions. Mexico is coming, right. So they could've come to last week or two weeks ago but now they're coming.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: You could read between there that it's not exactly the best economics in his answer. But perhaps --

(CROSSTALKING)

BAIER: He is getting --

(CROSSTALKING)

HUME: Yes. Kevin Hassett is the most cheerful man, by the way, probably in the world. Clearly he's not -- I don't think he is a big fan of tariffs. And tariffs seem to have now emerged as a weapon of choice for the President for all causes. For economic reasons and now for border control reasons.

The consequences of that is the fat's in the fire. The fat's in the fire with China. The fat's in the fire now with Mexico. The fat's in the fire in his -- not because of tariffs -- but in his dealings with North Korea.

So the President has a lot going -- a lot of pots on the stove and all of them may come up just fine. But, you know, there's a lot of risk ahead and you see the risk and the anxiety that it causes reflected in the behavior of the stock market.

BAIER: That's right. Brit -- as always, thank you.

HUME: You bet.

BAIER: Well, Congress is returning from it's spring break with a summer full of impeachment talk on the horizon. Another major issue, as we just talked about, the growing tension with our southern neighbor over immigration and trade.

Chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel on Capitol Hill tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: A high-level Mexican delegation is in Washington trying to prevent new tariffs from kicking in next week. The foreign minister warned escalating tariffs would cause pain on both sides of the border and could have unintended consequences.

MARCELO EBRARD, MEXICAN FOREIGN MINISTER: Tariffs could cause financial and economic instability which means that Mexico could reduce its capacity to address the migration flows.

EMANUEL: President Trump is not backing down, tweeting today, "As a sign of good faith, Mexico should immediately stop the flow of people and drugs through their country and to our southern border. They can do it if they want."

Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney warned yesterday President Trump isn't bluffing.

MICK MULVANEY, ACTING WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: I fully expect these tariffs to go on to at least the 5 percent level on June 10th. The President is deadly serious about fixing the situation at the southern border.

EMANUEL: President Trump announced Sunday Kevin Hassett who's chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, is leaving but Hassett insists it's not due to tariffs.

HASSETT: This is something that's been in in the works for a little while.

EMANUEL: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi refused to speak to reporters today when she returned to Capitol Hill where at least 55 of her Democrats are now in favor of impeachment.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: And our patriotic young --

EMANUEL: That was not the case Saturday when Pelosi was interrupted by a restless audience shouting for impeachment.

PELOSI: With the power of the gavel, we will continue to legislate to make progress for the American people.

But we will also investigate to defend our democracy and to hold this president and his administration accountable.

EMANUEL: But President Trump said she's getting booed because she's getting distracted by her base.

TRUMP: Well, you know why? Because people want her to do work. People want the Democrats to pass immigration laws.

EMANUEL: Much of the impeachment talk came out of the Russia probe and White House senior advisor Jared Kushner raised some eyebrows when asked if he would call the FBI if the Russians offered information again.

JARED KUSHNER, WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISER: I don't know. It's hard to do hypotheticals. But the reality is that we were not given anything that was salacious.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: The top Democrat on Senate Intelligence, Mark Warner of Virginia, pounced saying if a foreign adversary offers assistance to your campaign, you have a moral obligation to call the FBI -- Bret.

BAIER: Mike Emanuel, live on the Hill. Mike -- thanks.

House Democrats are giving Attorney General William Barr and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross until Thursday to turn over subpoena documents or face contempt citations. Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings is seeking information about the motive for the administration's inclusion of a citizenship question in next year's census.

Meanwhile tonight, George Nader, a Lebanese-American businessman who tried to set up foreign meetings during the Trump transition and ended up cooperating extensively with special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, has been arrested on charges of transporting child pornography. He was taken into custody upon arrival at JFK Airport.

Stocks were mixed today. The Dow gained 5. The S&P 500 dropped 8. The Nasdaq entered correction territory with a loss of 120.

President Trump may be the biggest and most obvious punching bag for Democrats hoping to earn a shot at replacing him. But the front runner in the race also becoming more of a target for those chasing him.

Correspondent Peter Doocy has tonight's campaign news from Dubuque, Iowa.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The question is how could Democrats beat President Trump?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Socialism is not the answer.

DOOCY: Supporters of socialist policies made themselves heard this weekend in California where activists saw a collection of candidates who took advantage of the frontrunner's absence. Elizabeth Warren suggested Joe Biden isn't bold enough.

SENATOR ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Some Democrats in Washington believe the only changes we can get are tweaks and nudges. If they dream at all, they dream small.

DOOCY: Pete Buttigieg seemed to critique Biden and Obama.

PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: There is no back to normal. A president like this doesn't even come within cheating distance of the Oval Office unless there is something deeply wrong with the old normal.

DOOCY: Then Bernie Sanders repeated his call for a political revolution.

SENATOR BERNIE SANDERS (D-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We cannot go back to the old ways. We have got to go forward.

DOOCY: Biden didn't directly or indirectly engage any of the candidates trying to catch him, instead focusing his attention on the incumbent he hopes to challenge -- President Trump -- at a human rights campaign dinner in Columbus.

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This White House has literally, literally a bully pulpit, is callously extending his power over the most vulnerable. Implementing discriminatory policies like Muslim bans, turning away asylum-seekers, putting children in cages.

DOOCY: Far behind Biden in the polls, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand is just hoping for a spot at the highest profile event of the cycle, the DNC's debate this month, appealing for more individual campaign donors with a call to women watching her town hall.

SENATOR KIRSTEN GILLIBRAND (D-NY), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We want women to have a seat at the table.

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: What about men?

GILLIBRAND: They are already there, do you not know?

DOOCY: Eric Swalwell is also struggling to make the debate stage so now he's bringing in his infant to help.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOOCY: Most candidates are content just to take a photo holding a baby, but Eric Swalwell is trying something totally different there with a strategy you could call "hope and change a diaper"-- Bret.

BAIER: Wow. Peter -- thank you.

Lawmakers in the House are preparing for a fourth try in just a minutes at a $19 billion disaster relief bill. The formal roll call vote on the suspension bill will require a two-thirds majority to pass.

After the Senate ok'd the measure a week and a half ago, three Republican objected delaying passage.

The point man for President Trump's Middle East peace plan says Palestine - - Palestinians are not yet capable of governing themselves. Senior advisor and presidential son-in-law Jared Kushner said in an interview with Axios he hopes Palestinians will be able to run their own affairs eventually.

His remarks come as the "Washington Post" reports audio from a meeting with Jewish leaders indicate Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is not counting on success with that Middle East plan and neither is the President.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: We'll see what I think any fair person would describe as a very detailed, one might argue, unexecutable but a very detailed economic outline of what success might look like in the entire region.

TRUMP: We're doing our best to help the Middle East to get a peace plan. And he may be right. I mean most people would say that. I think we have a good chance, but we'll see what happens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The plan is set to be released during a conference in Bahrain at the end of the month.

Back here at home, Transportation Department officials say Secretary Elaine Chao has been the champion of the American maritime industry. But the "New York Times" is reporting on what some consider uncomfortably close ties between Chao, who is married to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and her family's shipping business dealings in China.

Correspondent Doug McKelway has the story and the pushback.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: A spokesman for Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao called today's front page "New York Times" story a lie. A source close to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says it's deeply flawed.

The paper alleges that Chao and her husband McConnell have used their influence and power to gain mutual benefit from her family's business -- the Foremost Group, an American shipping company that does millions of dollars of business with China.

Its CEO is Angela Chao, Elaine's sister. She replaced their now retired father James, seen here at Chao's confirmation hearing.

ELAINE CHAO, U.S. TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY: I am especially delighted to introduce my father, Dr. James Chao.

MCKELWAY: The "Times" cites this October 2017 email from a U.S. embassy official in China written to superiors on the eve of Chao's planned visit to Beijing. The body of it is entirely redacted. But the "Times" quotes people allegedly familiar with the e-mail, including David Rank, the now retired deputy chief of mission in Beijing who says that Chao asked federal officials to help coordinate travel arrangements for at least one family member and include relatives in meetings with government officials.

Chao never made the trip. Her office tells Fox News it didn't occur for multiple reasons, including scheduling and two meetings at the White House.

The story alleges that Chao and Leader McConnell received millions of dollars in campaign contributions and gifts from her father. McConnell acknowledged the legal gifts in the "Times" story, apparently given after the death of Chao's mother. He said quote, "I'm proud to have had the support of my family over the years."

One government watchdog with more than 30 years experience sums up the "Times" lengthy expose.

THOMAS SCHATZ, CITIZENS AGAINST GOVERNMENT WASTE: It's a giant story about nothing. There's nothing new. There's nothing newsworthy. This story is boring. It's long. And it's really useless.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCKELWAY: McConnell's former chief of staff tweeted "Imagine for one moment that Elaine Chao was Elaine Johnson and her family emigrated from England. Do you think the "New York Times" would be interested in publishing that story? Bret.

BAIER: All right. Doug-- thank you.

Well, the U.S. Supreme Court is refusing to make a quick decision on an administration challenge over its immigration policy, Justices turn down a request to hear an appeal now of a lower court decision allowing for the DACA program for young immigrants to continue. The Justices made no comment in their order.

Up next, why the homeless epidemic in Los Angeles is being blamed for serious illnesses among police officers. We'll bring you there.

First here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 2 in San Francisco where teachers from dozens of schools in Union City and Hayward returned to the picket lines as their strike enters its third week. This comes after the New Haven Teachers Union made a counteroffer to the district in hopes of ending that walk out.

Fox 26 in Houston, as authorities say human remains found in Arkansas last week have been identified as those of missing four-year-old Texas girl Maleah Davis. Her mother's former fiance had claimed the girl was abducted. He's in jail on an evidence-tampering charge.

And this is a live look at St. Louis from Fox 2, our affiliate there. The big story there tonight, the surging Missouri and Mississippi Rivers are overtopping and busting some agricultural levees as flood waters make their way downstream. Some rural areas are being evacuated tonight. The Army Corps of Engineers says the Missouri River levee that protects an area of nearly -- near 1,400-person town of Winfield breached Sunday. We will follow that flooding as it continues.

That's tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT. We'll be right back.

BAIER: One of the largest blood testing providers in the country says its financial and medical information has been hacked. Qwest Diagnostics says data on almost 12 million customers was accessed by an unauthorized user between last August and this March. It says it is still working with forensic experts to determine the extent of the breach.

Boeing has told the FAA some of the parts on its grounded 737 Max airplanes may have been improperly manufactured. It says as many as 148 parts on the Max and next-generation models could have problems. The Max planes were taken out of service following two deadly crashes since last fall.

Some Los Angeles police officers are becoming ill because of the city's homeless epidemic. Tonight national correspondent William La Jeunesse tells us how that situation became so dangerous.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It is unsanitary around here, especially with these people using the bathroom in the street. No one picks up after themselves.

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Rotting food, trash, used syringes, human waste -- the city of Los Angeles becoming of dumpsters says the "L.A. Times". Even the police stations here in Skid Row is infested with rats.

SGT. JERRETTA SANDOZ, L.A. POLICE PROTECTIVE LEADER: It's disgusting. We want them to clean up immediately and make sure that all the toxins are away from the officers and their families.

LA JEUNESSE: A detective there is being treated for typhoid fever and five others show symptoms.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Is it ok, Mama.

LA JEUNESSE: Other officers who interact with the homeless are battling an outbreak of staph infections and hepatitis.

ERIC GARCETTI (D), LOS ANGELES MAYOR: Any police officers is sick I want to make sure they are protected, whether it's an issue with the plumbing in the station or something else.

LA JEUNESSE: Mayor Eric Garcetti is taking heat for failure to handle the city's 55,000 homeless. Shelter construction behind schedule and over budget. Homeless crime up 50 percent, says LAPD.

Taxpayers approved a billion dollars in spending to help the homeless but now residents even in the most liberal areas are suing to stop construction of new shelters.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: Residents are also fighting back using their phones. An app called My 311 allows Angelenos to report homeless camps and check the response online. Even though areas do get cleaned up users say the homeless eventually return -- Bret.

BAIER: William -- thank you.

Up next, watch out Google, Facebook, Amazon -- it appears the government is going after big tech. We'll explain.

First beyond our borders tonight.

A senior North Korean official who was reportedly sentenced to hard labor over the failed nuclear summit with the U.S. was shown in state media today enjoying a concert near leader Kim Jong-un. North Korean publications showed Kim Yong-chol sitting five seats away from Kim Jong-un clapping in the same row as other top officials during a musical performance by the wives of Korean people's army officers.

Russia is said to be withdrawing defense advisers from Venezuela. President Trump said in a tweet quote, "Russia has informed us that they have removed most of their people from Venezuela." The "Wall Street Journal" reporting the move comes as a regime of disputed President Nicolas Maduro is unable to pay for their support.

There are new calls for restrictions on cruise ships in Venice following the crash of an out-of-control vessel Sunday. That ship rammed into a dock and tourist river boat on a busy Venice canal. Officials say five people were injured in that incident.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back.

BAIER: The House Judiciary Committee is pulling the trigger on an expected investigation into big tech companies. "The Hill" reports tonight Democrats and Republicans on the committee just made that announcement. They will try to determine if companies such as Facebook, Google, and Amazon use their considerable market power to suppress competition.

Meantime, this was the deadliest weekend of the year so far in Chicago. Dozens were shot, almost a dozen killed. Correspondent Ellison Barber shows us what's happening in that city tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ELLISON BARBER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Chicago's most violent weekend of 2019 began before the sunset on Friday. By the time the weekend ended, police say 52 people were shot and 10 were dead, eight fatally shot, two fatally stabbed. The stabbings, police say, appear to be domestic related. The shooting mostly tied to gangs.

ELGIN HOLT, CHICAGO POLICE DEPUTY CHIEF: Unfortunately, many of the Southside districts have been plagued with violence related to guns, gangs, and drugs for too long. And this weekend brought with it more of the same.

BARBER: Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson claims the problem has little to do with the enforcement.

EDDIE JOHNSON, CHICAGO POLICE SUPERINTENDENT: We know who a lot of these people are. And how do we know that? Because we keep arresting them over and over and over and over again. Until we hold violent offenders accountable the way that they should be, we're going to continue to see this.

BARBER: Chicago's new mayor, Lori Lightfoot, a political outsider, ran on cleaning up the city and, among other things, stopping the city's, quote, "epidemic of violence. Mayor Lightfoot met with the police superintendent today. She has been on the job for two weeks.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I pray for the mayor because she has her hands full.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: Police say they seized 92 illegal guns this weekend and arrested 18 people on gun related charges. They say they're still looking for some suspects they believe are tied to the weekend's violence. Police say they are also ramping up patrols in the event of any retaliatory violence. Bret?

BAIER: Ellison Barber in Chicago tonight. Ellison, thank you.

Authorities in Virginia Beach are still not publicly speculating on a motive for Friday's shooting massacre at a municipal building there. Twelve people were killed. The gunman, who also died, apparently gave no indication he was about to undertake his deadly mission. Correspondent Mark Meredith is in Virginia Beach tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MARK MEREDITH, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hundreds of Virginia Beach residents spent Monday visiting a makeshift memorial built to honor the 12 people killed in Friday's massacre.

ROBYN JOHNSON, VIRGINIA BEACH MOURNER: It just makes me sick that you would take such bright people away from us.

MEREDITH: Robyn Johnson fought back tears after seeing 12 white crosses set up, each bearing the victim's name. Eleven of the victims were city employees, the 12th, a contractor who was in the building filing for a permit.

LISA BURCH, VIRGINIA BEACH MOURNER: Just terrible to think about what the families are going through.

MEREDITH: Police say the suspect, a city engineer for 15 years, emailed his regulation Friday morning, writing "It has been a pleasure to serve the city, but due to personal reasons I must relieve my position." Hours later police say the gunman opened fire on his coworkers.

JAMES CERVERA, VIRGINIA BEACH POLICE CHIEF: I do not have the exact number of rounds that the perpetrator fired. It was well into the double digits. As this suspect was firing, he was moving.

MEREDITH: Police say officers risked their own lives, rushing in to stop the gunman, eventually killing him. Johnson says even if police figure out the motive, Friday's rampage will still never make any sense to her.

JOHNSON: There's no reason. If you're angry, there's still no reason you should never take someone else's life.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MEREDITH: The city's police chief says four survivors remain in the hospital. Meanwhile, city office buildings that were closed today, they are expected to reopen for business tomorrow. But the building where the shooting took place, that remains closed. Bret?

BAIER: Mark Meredith live in Virginia Beach tonight. Mark, thanks.

President Trump with the pomp and circumstance in Great Britain, plus some ruffled feathers, and as his son-in-law does the same with the Palestinians. We'll get reaction from all of that with the panel when we come back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We'll be going to the U.K. I think it will be very important. It certainly will be very interesting.

JEREMY HUNT, BRITISH FOREIGN SECRETARY: This is a state visit. This is not a political visit. He's being hosted by her majesty the queen to mark the great friendship between our two countries.

SADIQ KHAN, LONDON MAYOR: The thing about a best friend is, of course you stand shoulder to shoulder with them in times of adversity. But you've got to call them out when you think they're wrong. I don't think we should be rolling out the red carpet. I don't think this should be a state visit.

TRUMP: I don't think much of him. I think that he's the twin of the de Blasio except shorter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: President Donald Trump in Great Britain talking in the back-and- forth of Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, who wrote an op-ed in "The Guardian" saying that the U.K. should not be welcoming the president of the United States, which is quite something. Before landing the president tweeted "Sadiq Khan, who by all accounts has done a terrible job as mayor of London, who has been foolishly nasty to the president of the United States, by far the most important ally of the United Kingdom. He is a stone cold loser should focus on crime in London, not me."

Despite that back-and-forth, a lot of the focus today, the pomp and circumstance all seemed to go well with the state dinner there in London. Let's bring in our panel, Matthew Continetti, editor in chief of the "Washington Free Beacon," Mara Liasson, national political correspondent for National Public Radio, and Mollie Hemingway, senior editor at "The Federalist." Matthew, obviously a lot of focus on the promised protest, even though we haven't seen much of that as of yet. There will be a lot of focus on the balloon that is supposed to fly over London. But today was about the relationship ahead of the 75th anniversary of D-Day. That was kind of an interesting image.

MATTHEW CONTINETTI, EDITOR IN CHIEF, "WASHINGTON FREE BEACON": I think the first thing to say, this is going to make a very interesting season of "The Crown." I don't know when we can anticipate that. Maybe a few years from now.

The second thing is, there's the pomp and circumstance, which is important, but then there's the substance facing the Trump administration in its relationship with the United Kingdom. And there are several issues that need to be worked out, from Brexit to a trade deal to the British government's cooperation with Huawei, the tech giant that we are fighting, the Chinese-backed enterprise. All of these things depend, though, on the replacement of Theresa May as prime minister, and until that is resolved, none of the other issues I think can actually be attended to.

BAIER: Mollie?

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, SENIOR EDITOR, "THE FEDERALIST": I think also one of the other issues that there's this big subtext here is this global issue of rising nationalism and populism versus elite control. Great Britain is having such issues here where you actually had people vote to exit the European Union, and people just trying to refused to do what the people want.

Donald Trump represents this global movement. As you see those tensions coming in the play, and so I'm not surprised to see some of the people who represent the people who don't want to respond or who are the people who don't want to respond to the will of the people not reacting so well to him.

BAIER: Here is Boris Johnson, rather, Sadiq Khan and President Trump talking about Boris Johnson, possibly a replacement for Theresa May.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SADIQ KHAN, LONDON MAYOR: I spent my first three years as mayor spending too much time cleaning up his mess. The idea that Boris Johnson's record as mayor is an application for the job of being prime minister I find astonishing.

DONALD TRUMP, (R) PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I like him. I've always liked him. I don't know that he's going to be chosen, but I think he's a very good guy, a very talented person. I could help anybody by endorsing them. We have had endorsements where they've gone up from 40, 50 points at a shot. That's here, but I understand over there that it would be a great endorsement. Other people have asked me for an endorsement, too. I've been asked for endorsements.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Obviously he's asked all of these questions, and sometimes they create a firestorm, but he's asked the questions. And it's ahead of the meeting with Theresa May.

MARA LIASSON, NATIONAL POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO: Yes, it's ahead of the meeting with Theresa May. He chose to respond to the mayor of London. He's really punching down. I think that that was a fight that he chose to engage in. But Donald Trump believes if you're not fighting, you're losing. So yes, he has this meeting with Theresa May, which apparently is not an extended bilateral. It's going to be quite short. But as Matthew said, they have a lot of really important issues.

BAIER: Her time in office is --

LIASSON: Her time in office is short, but they still need to talk about some of these other issues. And now Trump, once again, and he's done this before when he's gone to England, gotten involved in internal English politics.

BAIER: I want to turn now to Jared Kushner who gave an interview with "Axios" that aired over the weekend. This is the part about the meeting, the Russian meeting at Trump Tower and the fallout from it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONATHAN SWAN, NATIONAL POLITICS REPORTER, "AXIOS": We are talking about Russia here. They are a longtime adversary of the United States, decades of hostility, including spying. Does it not set off at least some alarm bell when you see an email saying that the Russian government wants to help?

JARED KUSHNER, WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISER: Like I said, the email that I got on my iPhone at the time because said show up at 4:00. I didn't scroll down. I never would've thought about that.

SWAN: It had "Russia" in the subject line.

KUSHNER: Again, I would get about 250 emails a day. And so I literally say show up at 4:00. I showed up at 4:00.

SWAN: Would you call the FBI if it happened again?

KUSHNER: I don't know. It's hard to do hypotheticals, but the reality is is that we were not given anything that was salacious.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Matthew?

CONTINETTI: I think Kushner has made a lot of his influence known in the administration working behind the scenes on two plans. One is the Middle East peace plan, and the other is the immigration plan. Both of those plans are running into trouble because of event that are outside of his control. This interview, on the other hand, was largely within his control. And I think he left a lot of questions unanswered as a result.

BAIER: Mollie?

HEMINGWAY: I would love to say, though, this interview is a great example of how bad our media are at covering the present moment. To be asked a question about Russia when we just came through two years of this Russia hoax conspiracy theory, and you have questions about whether you should've taken a meeting or whatnot. To actually have --

BAIER: The question, hold on, hold on.

LIASSON: -- it was not a hoax at all.

BAIER: Timeout. The question was, would you call the FBI if it happened again. Robert Mueller did say there was the threat that Russia is going to do it again. I understand what you're saying. Hold on. Let me just say that the question was about would you call the FBI.

HEMINGWAY: Sure, but the point being you actually have the FBI, which is implicated in perpetuating this hoax. You don't have the media asking tough questions about that. You don't have the media asking tough questions about the campaign that actually did work with Russians to meddle in our elections by putting together this dossier which they claim was sourced to Russian government officials, and to still be living in this conspiracy theory is just absurd.

And so I'm not saying he answered the question particularly well, but this is just -- at some point, the media are going to have to deal with the fact that this Russia collusion conspiracy theory was debunked, and not a single American was indicted for treasonous collusion with Russia, and that nothing has been dealt with in terms of Hillary Clinton's meddling with secretly hiring people to --

BAIER: When do you think that moment is going to happen, the I.G. report, the other reports, Bill Barr, where do you think it's going to happen?

HEMINGWAY: It just seems that no matter what comes out, the media are working very hard to avoid dealing with the reality of what happened.

BAIER: You don't think it was a fair question to ask Jared Kushner whether he would call the FBI if it happened again?

HEMINGWAY: It's fine. But that one question versus the hundreds of questions we have about what happened at the FBI, what happened at the Department of Justice --

BAIER: OK, but he is not the guy to answer that question.

LIASSON: -- talked about any of those things.

HEMINGWAY: These are questions all media people can ask all people.

BAIER: And Jared could have answered anyway he wanted to. He didn't.

Last word?

LIASSON: I think this was a mistake for him to have given this interview, I really do. And we could've played some other clips that also didn't reflect that well on him.

BAIER: All right, next up, the 2020 Democrats take aim at Joe Biden.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, (D-VT) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: There is a debate among presidential candidates who have spoken to you here in this room, and those who have chosen for whatever reason not to be in this room.

MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG, (D-IN) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: In these times Democrats can no more keep a promise to take us back to the 2000s or the 1990s, than conservatives can keep a promise to take us back to the 1950s. We can only look forward.

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, (D-MA) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Some Democrats in Washington believe the only changes we can get are tweaks and nudges. Our country is in a time of crisis. The time for small ideas is over.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Remember in Harry Potter where they couldn't say "Voldemort"? It was kind of like that. They couldn't say "Biden," but they were talking about Joe Biden, as you see in this California Democratic Convention. Now you look the average of recent poll, the Real Clear Politics average, Joe Biden, as you see, has a big lead. It's hard to read all of these names because there's so many of them, but there you have the breakdown.

But here's the early states, and this is important, Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina, also Biden with leads. Obviously, Iowa the closest there. And we're back with the panel. It seems like as we get closer and closer to this first debate, Mara, that there's going to be more swinging at Joe Biden.

LIASSON: More swinging. I think the biggest imperative for everybody on that stage is just to stand out and to say look at me. But Joe Biden didn't have to be at the Democratic Convention because you just showed the math. But I do think, I am hearing from Democrats that one thing he does need to do before the first debate is come out with some big, bold policies. They don't have to be leftwing policies, but they have to be some policies, which he has resisted doing with the exception of an education speech, because he hasn't had to so far.

But being a frontrunner in the Democratic primary is historically very precarious. And I think he needs to give people a reason to be excited about him, not just to think he's electable.

BAIER: As evidence, and probably one of the reasons he didn't go to the Democratic Convention in California, John Delaney and John Hickenlooper.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN DELANEY, (D) PRESIDENT CANDIDATE: Medicare for all may sound good, but it's actually not good policy nor is it good politics. I'm telling you.

(BOOS)

JOHN HICKENLOOPER, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Let me be clear. If we want to beat Donald Trump and achieve big, progressive goals, socialism is not the answer. I was reelected.

(BOOS)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Matthew?

CONTINETTI: In 2012 at the Democratic Convention, the crowd booed mentions of Jerusalem and God in the party platform. In 2019, they are booing denunciations of socialism. Give them a few months, they will be booing mom and apple pie. This is your Democratic Party at work.

BAIER: So obviously Biden doesn't want to go into that place.

HEMINGWAY: I do think getting booed there is not necessarily the worst.

BAIER: It will probably be in an ad.

HEMINGWAY: So it's a problem that the Democratic Party has that their base are getting further and further to the left whereas they need to appeal to moderate people. That's Biden's strength, of course. And he didn't need to be there, but I'm worried that once he makes policies that are more specific that there might be much more room to --

LIASSON: I'm interested in seeing that, and I bet he's going to do just fine without lurching to the left. But the thing about Hickenlooper that's so amazing, he's the guy who was asked in an interview not long ago, are you a capitalist, and he couldn't say that he was.

BAIER: He couldn't say.

LIASSON: And he's a former businessman. That's his whole brand.

HEMINGWAY: It's also interesting that you had all these candidates speaking about Medicare for all or getting booed for not supporting it. It really is stunning how quickly Obamacare has fallen into something that people don't think is defendable or --

LIASSON: It's the Twitter part of the Democratic Party and the California Democratic Party. Most Democrats, I think we could probably find some polling on it, are happy to have Obamacare and a public option.

BAIER: Here we go, the Kaiser poll, number two, where should Democrats focus their efforts on approving health care, improving and protecting Obamacare. You have a question. We have a poll for you.

(LAUGHTER)

BAIER: Matthew, where do you think it goes? Obviously, we have a long, long way to go before we get to anybody voting.

CONTINETTI: Biden's lead has been durable, but as you see in that poll that you showed of Iowa, that is a very precarious lead in the early states. I would say other than ganging up on Biden in the beginning, the other big story from this convention was Kamala Harris continues to underwhelm. She actually had the microphone stolen from her during one panel, and her response betrayed a candidate who was kind of uncertain and uninsured.

LIASSON: Some guy comes on stage, you should --

BAIER: Moveon.org, you can't fault her. But you can look at this poll in California where she is the sitting senator, and this is not good.

LIASSON: That's the interesting thing, not so much what she did when that animal rights guy came on the --

CONTINETTI: I'm telling you, it happened in 2016, and it shows something about the candidates, even if it's -- we don't know what we would do in the same thing, but can you see Donald Trump giving of the microphone voluntarily?

LIASSON: We've seen Donald Trump flinch on the stage when some guy rushed it. This is --

BAIER: I'm not sure what he would do. Five seconds.

HEMINGWAY: Biden is strong, but the moment he shows some weakness, it could all collapse quickly.

LIASSON: Because his whole thing is about I can beat him.

BAIER: We've seen it before. When we come back, keeping heroism in the family.

BAIER: Finally tonight, it's all in the family. 101-year-old, Walter Kloc, traveled from New York to Colorado to commission his grandson, Joseph at his graduation from the Air Force Academy last week. Walter, a World War II veteran was an Air Force bombardier pilot. Joseph was commissioned as a second lieutenant and Walter received the standing ovation. Great stuff. We'll see a lot of that from D-Day this week. Big week when you think about World War II.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced, and unafraid. Speaking of that, "THE STORY", hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now. She's heading over there.

Martha?

urn:contentItem:60R9-FTD1-JBHT-D3F4-00000-00Pompeo calls for ‘Clean Fortress’ to protect US data from China2020-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPompeo calls for ‘Clean Fortress’ to protect US data from ChinaJerry DunleavyWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

The State Department expanded its “Clean Network” program efforts by calling for a “Clean Fortress” to protect information and communications in the United States from foreign countries such as China as the Trump administration contemplates a ban on Chinese-owned TikTok.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made the announcement on Wednesday, building on the Trump administration’s “comprehensive approach to guarding our citizens’ privacy and our companies’ most sensitive information from aggressive intrusions by malign actors, such as the Chinese Communist Party” by adding five new lines of effort, dubbed Clean Carrier, Clean Store, Clean Apps, Clean Cloud, and Clean Cable.

"Building a Clean Fortress around our citizens’ data will ensure all of our nations’ security," Pompeo said.

The Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations released a report in June detailing how China is focusing on U.S. communications the same way it has targeted education, research, and personal data. The investigation found the Chinese government “exerts control over China’s domestic telecommunications industry and state-owned carriers” while it “engages in cyber and economic espionage efforts against the United States" and "may use telecommunications carriers operating in the United States to further these efforts."

Pompeo announced the Clean Path initiative in April, aimed at implementing the 5G Clean Path guidelines outlined in the 2019 National Defense Authorization Act, part of the U.S. effort to protect its fifth-generation wireless systems and other telecommunications from being compromised by Chinese Big Tech firms such as Huawei or by other foreign actors. "The objective is that untrusted IT vendors will have no access to U.S. State Department systems” and that “we will keep doing all we can to keep our critical data and our networks safe from the Chinese Communist Party," Pompeo said.

This week’s announcement builds on that, as Pompeo said that Clean Carrier efforts will ensure that “untrusted” Chinese carriers “are not connected” to U.S. telecom networks due to concerns about national security; Clean Store requirements will aim to “remove untrusted applications from U.S. mobile app stores” because Chinese apps “threaten our privacy, proliferate viruses, and spread propaganda and disinformation”; Cleans Apps guidelines will prevent “untrusted” Chinese smartphone manufacturers from pre-installing or making available for download “trusted apps” on their apps store so as to keep U.S. companies from promoting apps on phones produced by companies such as Huawei, which have been linked to human rights abuses; Clean Cloud efforts will protect personal data and intellectual property from being stored on cloud systems that are “accessible to our foreign adversaries” through Chinese tech firms such as Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent; and Clean Cable rules will “ensure the undersea cables connecting our country to the global internet are not subverted for intelligence gathering” by China.

Pompeo also told reporters that he is joining Attorney General William Barr, Defense Secretary Mark Esper, and acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf in “urging” the Federal Communications Commission to “revoke and terminate” the authorizations of China Telecom and three other companies providing services to and from the U.S.

The announcement follows President Trump’s comments on Monday that TikTok would “close down” in the U.S. by Sept. 15 unless Microsoft or another U.S. company works out a deal approved by his administration to buy the video-sharing social media platform. TikTok is owned by Chinese internet technology company ByteDance, which is based in Beijing.

ByteDance and TikTok have repeatedly claimed that they have not and would never turn over TikTok user data to the Chinese government, but national security experts have raised concerns about China’s own 2017 national intelligence law, which requires all Chinese companies to assist Chinese intelligence services when asked — and to keep it secret.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, the chairman of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, said on Sunday that “the entire committee agrees that TikTok cannot stay in the current format because it risks sending back information on a hundred million Americans.”

The House voted by a large margin to block federal employees from using TikTok in July, and the Senate joined them on Wednesday. The ban is expected to become law soon. Joe Biden's campaign told staff to delete TikTok from their phones. The Pentagon banned service members from using TikTok in late 2019, and the Transportation Security Administration, Department of Homeland Security, and State Department also banned TikTok on government devices.

Trump's April executive order established the “Committee for the Assessment of Foreign Participation in the United States Telecommunications Services Sector” after years of there being an informal Team Telecom. The order said the “security, integrity, and availability” of U.S. telecom networks was “vital” to U.S. national security.

Barr was named the formal head of Team Telecom, tasked with working with the FCC to ensure foreign foes do not gain undue access to or control over U.S. communications networks.

The Justice Department backed the FCC’s successful plan late last year to block Chinese telecommunications companies such as Huawei and ZTE from receiving federal money to help build U.S. broadband infrastructure and supported the FCC’s proposal to replace any broadband equipment already in place that uses the Chinese company's equipment.

The U.S. also charged Huawei in a global racketeering scheme earlier this year, and U.S. intelligence agencies believe Huawei, ZTE, and other Chinese companies are working hand in hand with the Chinese Communist Party.

Federal agencies in the U.S. were banned in August 2019 from purchasing telecommunications products, surveillance equipment, or any other products or services from Huawei, ZTE Corporation, and three other Chinese companies. In a second and wider-ranging regulation that will be implemented this month, these agencies will also have to avoid doing business with any companies that buy products or services from the five Chinese companies.

urn:contentItem:5W9Y-MWT1-DXVP-V06T-00000-00Ponnuru: What Facebook can do to avoid regulation2019-06-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:01ZLexisNexisCOLUMNISTSPonnuru: What Facebook can do to avoid regulationRAMESH PONNURU

Conservatives remain convinced that the tech industry is biased against them. They point to evidence that Facebook, Twitter, Google and YouTube are staffed disproportionately by liberals, a fact that nobody seriously denies. In a fascinating essay for the New Atlantis, Adam White argues that there is a deep alignment between their corporate culture and the assumptions of modern liberalism.

A nearly inevitable result, conservatives say, is that the companies are more likely to try to suppress conservative content as offensive: taking down tweets and posts from righties and directing traffic elsewhere. The companies deny they have displayed bias, even as admit they have made occasional mistakes in content moderation.

One school of conservatives argues that while the tech titans' decisions may be wrong and worthy of condemnation, it is not government's business to regulate their decisions because they are private companies.

According to this reasoning, people who are unhappy with Facebook's policies should condemn or boycott it. They should cajole Twitter into adopting better policies. (One suggestion has been that Twitter act toward its users the same way the First Amendment makes the government act toward citizens.) Or they should try to start a rival site.

What these conservatives don't want is for government to force the companies to behave differently, beyond holding them to their own terms of service.

Another group on the right thinks that the hands-off approach is dogma unsuited to the world we actually inhabit. The social-media companies are too large a part of our society, and host too much of our political debate, for the government to leave them alone.

A leading voice for this second group is Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri. His criticisms of social-media companies are wide-ranging. He has gone so far as to question whether the talent they employ would be doing more good in other parts of the economy.

Political bias is among his main concerns. "Google and Facebook should not be a law unto themselves," he has said. "They should not be able to discriminate against conservatives. They should not be able to tell conservatives to sit down and shut up."

Soon after his election in 2018, Hawley argued that the big tech companies are benefiting from a government-granted privilege. He observed — on Twitter, naturally — that Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act gives these companies immunity from liability for content that appears on their sites.

They get this immunity, he suggested, on the condition that they serve as forums for "a true diversity of political discourse." He called for congressional investigations to see if they were meeting that condition. Congress has subsequently held hearings on it.

Republican Senator Ted Cruz, questioning Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, made the same point as Hawley: "The predicate for Section 230 immunity under the CDA is that you're a neutral public forum."

What they're saying: Facebook can be a message board with no responsibility for the messages tacked onto it. Or it can take an active role in shaping content, in which case it assumes legal responsibility for that content.

Those who fear government regulation in this area (and not just conservatives) have pushed back against Hawley and Cruz. They point out that the law also gives the companies immunity for actions they take against obscene, harassing or otherwise objectionable material, even if that material falls under the First Amendment.

It does not seem like too much for Congress to ask that the immunity it has provided be conditioned on some more transparency from the companies about how they decide what content to promote, hide or suppress. One possibility would be to require the companies to disclose summary information about how they make these decisions; another, perhaps easier to administer, would be to require them to publish a database of content they have deleted.

Before we decide either to regulate the tech companies or leave them alone, let's find out if the anecdotes of bias are just anecdotes, or something more.

urn:contentItem:5XH8-R5R1-F11P-X0KN-00000-00Pope demands more action from big tech firms to protect children2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:01ZLexisNexisPope demands more action from big tech firms to protect childrenDaniel Sanderson

Catholic leader speaks of concerns over impact of pornography on young minds at UAE-backed summit

Pope Francis meeting participants in the international congress on "Promoting Digital Child Dignity ". (Vatican Media)

Pope Francis has called on big internet companies to do more to protect children from abuse and online pornography at a Vatican conference hosted by the UAE.

In his address to the Congress on Promoting Digital Child Dignity, the 82-year-old said he was not persuaded by arguments, put forward by some large online firms, that they offered only 'platforms' for sharing content and were therefore not responsible for how they are used.

He also said there is a need to find a "fitting balance" between freedom of expression online and the interests of society, to ensure that digital media channels "are not used to perpetrate criminal activities against minors."

The event was addressed by Sheikh Saif bin Zayed, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior, who said the exploitation and abuse of children had become "a particular source of concern for the future of humanity".

Although Pope Francis did not mention any company by name, the summit was attended by representatives of firms including Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google.

While acknowledging that the internet had brought opportunities for young people, for example in education, he said that security agencies were struggling to keep up with the sharing of child abuse online.

He also raised concerns of long-term damage to children as a result of being exposed to online pornography at a young age.

"Reliable studies tell us that the average age of first access to pornography is currently eleven, and tends to keep lowering," the Catholic leader said. "This is in no way acceptable.

"The majority of scientific studies have highlighted the profound impact of pornography on the thinking and behaviour of children.

"It will surely have lifelong effects on them, in the form of grave addiction, violent behaviour and deeply troubled emotional and sexual relationships."

In comments targeted at big digital media companies, he said: "It is now clear that they cannot consider themselves completely unaccountable vis-à-vis the services they provide for their customers.

"So I make an urgent appeal to them to assume their responsibility towards minors, their integrity and their future. It will not be possible to guarantee the safety of minors in the digital world without the full involvement of companies in this sector and without a full awareness of the moral and social repercussions of their management and functioning.

"Such companies are bound not only to respect the law, but also to be concerned with the direction taken by the technological and social developments which they produce and promote, since such developments are far ahead of the laws that would seek to regulate them."

The summit is the latest in a series of events, backed by the UAE, aimed at addressing the issue of child safety in the digital age. A major summit was held in Abu Dhabi last year about the problem, following the Child Dignity in the Digital World congress, held in Rome in October 2017.

In his comments on Thursday, Pope Francis praised positive measures taken by some governments, such as requiring internet providers to implement age-verification checks. However, he said far more needed to be done by companies.

"There is a need to ensure that investors and managers remain accountable, so that the good of minors and society is not sacrificed to profit," he said.

"We have seen how society has grown more sensitive to the areas of environmental care and respect for the dignity of labour.

"A similar concern for the effective protection of minors and the fight against pornography should become increasingly felt in the finance and the economy of the digital world. The safe and sound growth of our young is a noble goal worth pursuing; it has far greater value than mere economic profit gained at the risk of harming young people."

The Pope's appearance at the summit jointly hosted by the UAE follows his historic visit to Abu Dhabi earlier this year.

Sheikh Saif made reference the visit in his remarks. The interfaith conference was also attended by Dr Ahmad Al Tayyeb, Grand Imam of Al Azhar Al Sharif.

"The people of the UAE welcomed His Holiness Pope Francis with joy and happiness last February during his landmark historical visit to the UAE, the first to the region, to an Arab and Muslim country that diligently endeavours to foster peaceful coexistence, and spread tolerance and love," Sheikh Saif said.

"What unites us as believers is far greater than what divides us. All religious denominations around the world condemn evil and call for cooperation, good deeds and respect for life."

During his trip Sheikh Saif met Queen Silvia of Sweden, a long-time activist for children's rights, and the Italian interior minister, Luciana Lamorgese.

Reem Abdullah Al Falasi, Secretary-General of the Supreme Council for Motherhood and Childhood, also addressed the Vatican conference.

"We still need greater international efforts to protect the world's children," she said. "New challenges and threats to the rights of the world's children have emerged, and the need for protection in the digital world is one of the most prominent of these threats and perhaps the most difficult to deal with, because, in the digital world, risks and abuses are hidden from the public."

Sheikh Saif and Pope Francis embrace during the summit.

Pope Francis has called on big internet companies to do more to protect children from abuse and online pornography at a Vatican conference hosted by the UAE.

In his address to the Congress on Promoting Digital Child Dignity, the 82-year-old said he was not persuaded by arguments, put forward by some large online firms, that they offered only 'platforms' for sharing content and were therefore not responsible for how they are used.

He also said there is a need to find a "fitting balance" between freedom of expression online and the interests of society, to ensure that digital media channels "are not used to perpetrate criminal activities against minors."

The event was addressed by Sheikh Saif bin Zayed, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior, who said the exploitation and abuse of children had become "a particular source of concern for the future of humanity".

While acknowledging that the internet had brought opportunities for young people, for example in education, he said that security agencies were struggling to keep up with the sharing of child abuse online.

He also raised concerns of long-term damage to children as a result of being exposed to online pornography at a young age.

"Reliable studies tell us that the average age of first access to pornography is currently eleven, and tends to keep lowering," the Catholic leader said. "This is in no way acceptable.

"The majority of scientific studies have highlighted the profound impact of pornography on the thinking and behaviour of children.

"It will surely have lifelong effects on them, in the form of grave addiction, violent behaviour and deeply troubled emotional and sexual relationships."

urn:contentItem:5Y0J-2SM1-JB4M-V3HV-00000-00PopSockets, Tile and other companies will ask Congress to help stop Big Tech bullying2020-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:01ZLexisNexisPopSockets, Tile and other companies will ask Congress to help stop Big Tech bullyingTony Romm

BOULDER, Colo. - David Barnett is an unlikely warrior in the battle against Big Tech. The founder and chief executive of PopSockets, a local company that makes a widely popular kickstand of sorts for smartphones, says he isn't even an "expert on antitrust laws" in Washington.

But Barnett discovered firsthand the rare power and influence of Amazon in 2018, after clashing with the e-commerce giant over policies that made it hard to sell his products on his preferred terms and prices. PopSockets soon terminated its ties with Amazon, which helped lead to sizable losses later as a result.

"What company that started a business out of their garage can afford to lose $10 million?" he asked in an interview. "We're lucky we're in a position we're profitable and could take a stand."

Barnett's story could resonate with federal regulators: Such tales of Big Tech's debatably brash, bullying tactics are set to take center stage when he and his corporate peers testify at a high-profile congressional hearing here Friday. The session could elicit the most convincing public evidence to date that Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Google have become too big and powerful - and need to be restrained.

Since June, House lawmakers led by Democratic Rep. David N. Cicilline (R.I.) have trained their sights on the four tech giants, exploring their ascendancy as the world's most popular and profitable online services. Even in a capital wracked by partisanship, Democrats and Republicans have come to share heightened concerns the industry's biggest players may have stifled competition, enriched themselves on Americans' personal data or locked in their digital dominance unlawfully.

The hearing - to be held not far from PopSockets' headquarters in Boulder - could ultimately serve to put a new, personal face on long-standing calls for tech titans to be regulated, penalized or broken up, galvanizing those who believe Congress needs to toughen federal antitrust laws to prevent abuse.

"You think about the market share that some of these platforms have," Cicilline said. "You change an algorithm, you exclude someone from a platform, and you can put them out of business."

Along with PopSockets, lawmakers are set to hear from top executives at Sonos, a high-end audio company, and Basecamp, which makes collaborative workplace software. Both allege Google undermines smaller rivals. Sonos has sued Google, alleging patent infringement.

Joining those witnesses will be a senior official from Tile, best known for its technology that helps people track keys, wallets and other objects they're liable to lose around the house. Company officials contend Apple's software tweaks stifle competing services.

Ahead of the hearing, tech giants vigorously defended their practices. Amazon in a statement said its seller rules benefit consumers, and it took issue with PopSockets and some of its claims. Google said its ad policies are fair and it never infringed on Sonos technology. Apple pointed to past comments saying it seeks to protect consumer privacy through its software updates, not undermine rivals. Facebook did not comment.

(Amazon founder and chief executive Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.)

The bipartisan congressional inquiry illustrates the precarious regulatory environment that looms over Silicon Valley, once the darling of a tech-obsessed Washington. The industry's rapid rise and record-breaking profits, long heralded as an engine of American economic growth, now are seen as evidence of the dangers of corporate consolidation.

In response, federal antitrust regulators have started to ponder action: The Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission last year divvied up competition oversight of the country's top tech companies. Nearly every state attorney general, meanwhile, has banded together for wide-ranging probes targeting Facebook and Google. On Thursday, Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser announced he had appointed three experienced lawyers to help with antitrust issues and investigations.

And Cicilline, the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee's antitrust-focused subcommittee, has spent seven months leading the panel as it peers under the hood of Big Tech.

So far, members of Congress have obtained millions of documents with the goal of putting forward bipartisan recommendations in the next few months. Cicilline said this week lawmakers soon also seek to question "the CEOs of some of the major technology companies," threatening an uncomfortable public grilling for Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Google.

The tech industry's top lobbyists say they understand the scrutiny. But they disagree vehemently with those who say that consumers have suffered and tech companies should be broken up as a result.

"There's no question that the disruptive innovations have created some winners and losers," said Matt Schruers, the president of the Computer and Communications Industry Association, which represents Amazon, Facebook and Google. "I don't think there's any doubt members of Congress are hearing from those who have been on the losing side of some of these disruptive innovations, but consumer response to these products speaks for itself."

Not everyone sees it that way.

Tile long had benefited from Apple's good graces: The company behind those tiny trackers for your most important possessions even had a rare shout-out onstage at the iPhone giant's annual developer conference in 2018.

But the relationship soured as Apple inched closer toward rolling out a tool - built into its smartphone operating system - that seemed like "something that's going to resemble our service," Kirsten Daru, Tile's general counsel, recalled in an interview ahead of her testimony Friday.

The result was "Find My," an enhanced effort by Apple to help its customers better locate their lost devices. Not only does it mimic many of the features long offered by Tile, but it also has a major advantage: Apple turned on the location tracking that makes "Find My" functional by default. Rivals like Tile, meanwhile, must obtain users' permission in deep, hard-to-find smartphone settings, Daru said, then reauthorize it when presented with follow-up reminders.

Apple said the changes are about protecting privacy, citing a need to prevent app-makers from using consumers' data without their knowledge. "Apple has not built a business model around knowing a customer's location or the location of their device," spokesman Fred Sainz said in a statement.

But Tile said the changes for now have resulted in a "confusing and frustrating experience for our users," according to Daru, adding: "We're looking to Congress to level the playing field."

David Heinemeier Hansson has a similar message for lawmakers. The well-known programmer and co-founder of Basecamp, which offers Web-based product management tools, said he plans to stress Friday that it's time for regulators to "broaden your definition of what antitrust enforcement is."

For Basecamp, the trouble centers on Google's dominant search engine, which aided the tech giant in amassing $117 billion in ad revenue in 2018. Basecamp's competitors have been purchasing ads on Google against the company's own name, he said, meaning people who search for Hansson's company see rivals unless they scroll down their results page. To Hansson, it means Google requires companies "to pay protection money" - or risk obscurity.

"They built their monopoly by having a great search engine," he said. "Now that they have that monopoly, they're exploiting it to reap monopoly profits."

In response, Google spokesman Jose Castaneda rebuffed Basecamp's claims. He said competitors are allowed to "bid on trademarked terms because it offers users more choice when they are searching," but he added Google will remove their names from text if they file a complaint.

By airing their criticisms publicly, many of Big Tech's biggest challengers seek to change the political calculus. Scores of companies long have been willing to grouse about their bigger tech brethren only privately, afraid of squandering much-needed relationships or scaring off investors wary of open warfare.

But renewed antitrust interest in Washington has some corporate boardrooms rethinking their plans, as they labor to attract the attention of regulators who say they are ready to do something about it. The troubles aired at the hearing Friday could later shape state and federal probes, leading to significant penalties, lawmakers and experts said.

"I don't think we've ever faced a situation where there's such a small group of companies with such unprecedented size, scale and dominance," said Patrick Spence, the chief executive of Sonos.

This month, the audio company revealed in court documents it is suing Google, alleging the search giant copied its technology. Google has denied the charge and this week claimed Sonos has made "misleading statements." But Spence said Google's behavior reflects a culture where big companies are "doing the math" and determining they can act as they please and survive the punishment. Sonos previously kept the standoff quiet for years, a sign to some about the fear of challenging the largest tech companies publicly.

"It might be life or death for them," Spence said.

To the average Amazon shopper, it might not have seemed anything was amiss with PopSockets, either. Their small, circular handles, attached to the back of iPhones and Androids, were readily available on the e-commerce site. But that obscured a lengthy, tense relationship between the two companies that later cost PopSockets millions of dollars, said Barnett, the leader of PopSockets.

In its earlier days, PopSockets tried to get Amazon's attention about counterfeits sold there, only to be browbeaten by the tech giant into spending more on marketing, according to Barnett. Adding to the headaches, PopSockets fretted about Amazon policies that essentially left it little choice but to sell directly to Amazon, which then determined the prices of the products it later sold to customers.

For its part, Amazon disputed that it asked PopSockets to pay more to help with counterfeits. And it attributed the larger debacle to the fact that PopSockets ran afoul of its rules. Those policies require some popular Amazon brands to sell their products to the e-commerce company, which then sells them to consumers. Amazon contends PopSockets instead sought to sell its smartphone accessories through an intermediary.

"Amazon obsesses over our customer experience, and we have policies for brands to ensure they are consistently meeting customer expectations," said Jack Evans, a spokesman at Amazon.

But Barnett said the restrictions proved too limiting. While he since has sought to restart his relationship with Amazon, the PopSockets leader recalled Amazon officials at one point trying - unsuccessfully - to strong-arm the company even after it reached its breaking point.

"They acted as if it wasn't in our power to break up with them," he said. "For most businesses our age, it's not in their power to break up with Amazon. It's not within their power to find an alternative."

urn:contentItem:5VPG-49D1-JCMN-Y4BD-00000-00Popular health apps could expose data about medical conditions2019-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:01ZLexisNexisPopular health apps could expose data about medical conditions

Mar 21, 2019( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) The study, titled "Commercial health apps: in the user's interest?[1]", looked at 24 popular health apps.

Of the 24, it was found that 19 of them shared user data with other companies. These third parties included Facebook, Google and Amazon. It also stands that these big tech players could easily sell on the data to other companies, without the user of the app being aware that this has happened. The security issue raises new concerns about who owns personal data - the company that owns the app or the user of the app?Who owns health data? There are many people or entities who could claim ownership[2] over a patient's medical information. Does the physician own it? The medical institution? Some third party? The complexity arises between ownership of information belonging to either the individual or the company who created the means to obtain the information. The complexity arises because some countries and indeed most states in U.S.[3] do not have law to confer specific ownership of medical data to patients. Questions of data ownership and what happens to the data are important, given the ever growing popularity of health apps. In a Rock Health survey[4], 90 percent of respondents reported using at least one digital health tool; this was an increase from 80 percent from the preceding 12 month period. The new research looked at[5] apps developed for the Android mobile platform and which are commercially available in the U.K., U.S., Canada and Australia. The study, led by Quinn Grundy at the University of Toronto, and published in the BMJ throws out a further concern[6] given that health data was shared despite statements from the developers that they do not collect personally identifiable information. However, the medical researchers showed that data could be traced back and hence users could be easily identified by piecing together data trails or metadata ('data about data'), like the user's Android phone's unique address. The study recommends that doctors should be warning their patients about the threat to their privacy from using such health apps and that government regulators need to consider that loss of privacy is not a fair cost for the use of digital health services.
